citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Each dog was checked for fleas in inspection. Eight dogs housed on the floor in the group runs were found to have one or
two live fleas on them, affecting each group (one dog having fleas in a group affects the whole group). None of the dams
in the raised whelping pens with puppies were found to have fleas or signs of fleas. The facility had contacted the
attending veterinarian on 7/8/2023 and recorded doing haircuts with baths (with soap), increased cleaning/sanitizing
through 7/15 and first gave a flea product (Capstar) to control fleas to most dogs on 7/26/2023 and the rest on 7/27 after
the attending veterinarian did physical exams and found fleas on dogs on 7/26/2023. The facility noted that a topical spray
has also been applied to dogs when fleas are observed but it is unclear to which dogs. I contacted the attending
veterinarian (AV) who said instructions need to be followed more closely. The AV also said that Capstar was discussed
but would need to be given daily for protection and other products with better flea protection were recommended. A note
from the clinic sent after the 7/26/2023 visit to the facility says that the product Zoguard should be started and 'the sooner
the better.' The caretaker said that a box of Zoguard arrived a couple of weeks ago but only one dog has received a dose.
Fleas can cause discomfort to dogs and can spread sickness. Flea populations inside a kennel can reproduce for months
if not controlled and very strict cleaning and sanitizing routines with acceptable treatments for dogs must be followed as
recommended by the attending veterinarian. Ensure to give the attending veterinarian appropriate authority for the health
of the dogs by closely following the treatment plan(s) given for the facility and dogs.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Dog #68 had an area of shaved hair and an area that was scabbed with some white discharge. The licensee said the
attending veterinarian said it was likely a cyst and could be monitored but possibly the animal caretaker/helper might have
started putting something on it. The scab and white discharge suggest an active problem and needs to be seen by the
attending veterinarian for treatment guidance. Ensure that this dog's skin problem is seen by the veterinarian and follow
the recommended treatment.

There is some loose paneling by the raised whelping enclosures that is collecting soiled material on the side. Collections
of soiled material can increase pest/disease risk in a facility.
The loose paneling does not allow for surfaces to be readily cleaned and sanitized and must be repaired/replaced. Ensure
to repair/replace the loose paneling.
Correct by 9/8/2023.

Two whelping enclosures had carpet sections that had frayed edges leaving loose strings in the area that the dog and
puppies walk. The loose strings are a risk for the dog or puppies to get tangled in. Ensure that carpets are maintained free
from loose strings.
Correct by 8/29/2023.

Dogs in the raised enclosure (#58 and #27) and a beagle (#66) with puppies had water dishes that were empty. Other
dogs in the facility have a continuous water system. When given water, these dogs drank in a manner that suggested they
were moderately thirsty. Lack of water can cause health problems in dogs. Ensure that all dogs have continuous access
to potable water.
Maintain correct by 8/29/2023.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
There was excessive soiled waste under the four raised whelping enclosures closest to the entry door. When examining
these dogs inside their enclosures stronger odors were noted and some flies were on the waste. The licensee said areas
underneath (where dogs don't contact it) is cleaned twice weekly. Since stronger odors were observed and flies were on
the waste, more frequent cleaning is needed of this area. Odors and flies can cause discomfort and sickness in dogs.
Ensure that areas under these enclosures are cleaned more often to prevent odors and pests such as flies.
Correct by 8/30/2023.

Facility representatives said a spray product (Adams Plus) has been used on dogs since July when fleas were seen. A
record of when and which dog was given this product wasn't kept. The names of treatments given and the dates they are
given and to which dog is required to be kept in records and is important for animal health monitoring. Ensure that
accurate records are kept that show what treatments were given to which animal and the date given.
Correct from this day forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(a)(2)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Each dog was checked for fleas in inspection. Eight dogs housed on the floor in the group runs were found to have one or 
two live fleas on them, affecting each group (one dog having fleas in a group affects the whole group). None of the dams 
in the raised whelping pens with puppies were found to have fleas or signs of fleas. The facility had contacted the 
attending veterinarian on 7/8/2023 and recorded doing haircuts with baths (with soap), increased cleaning/sanitizing 
through 7/15 and first gave a flea product (Capstar) to control fleas to most dogs on 7/26/2023 and the rest on 7/27 after 
the attending veterinarian did physical exams and found fleas on dogs on 7/26/2023. The facility noted that a topical spray 
has also been applied to dogs when fleas are observed but it is unclear to which dogs. I contacted the attending 
veterinarian (AV) who said instructions need to be followed more closely. The AV also said that Capstar was discussed 
but would need to be given daily for protection and other products with better flea protection were recommended. A note 
from the clinic sent after the 7/26/2023 visit to the facility says that the product Zoguard should be started and 'the sooner 
the better.' The caretaker said that a box of Zoguard arrived a couple of weeks ago but only one dog has received a dose.  
Fleas can cause discomfort to dogs and can spread sickness. Flea populations inside a kennel can reproduce for months 
if not controlled and very strict cleaning and sanitizing routines with acceptable treatments for dogs must be followed as 
recommended by the attending veterinarian. Ensure to give the attending veterinarian appropriate authority for the health 
of the dogs by closely following the treatment plan(s) given for the facility and dogs. 
2.40(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Dog #68 had an area of shaved hair and an area that was scabbed with some white discharge. The licensee said the 
attending veterinarian said it was likely a cyst and could be monitored but possibly the animal caretaker/helper might have 
started putting something on it. The scab and white discharge suggest an active problem and needs to be seen by the 
attending veterinarian for treatment guidance. Ensure that this dog's skin problem is seen by the veterinarian and follow 
the recommended treatment. 
3.1(c)(1) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
There is some loose paneling by the raised whelping enclosures that is collecting soiled material on the side. Collections 
of soiled material can increase pest/disease risk in a facility.

The loose paneling does not allow for surfaces to be readily cleaned and sanitized and must be repaired/replaced. Ensure 
to repair/replace the loose paneling.  
Correct by 9/8/2023. 
3.6(a)(2)(ii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Two whelping enclosures had carpet sections that had frayed edges leaving loose strings in the area that the dog and 
puppies walk. The loose strings are a risk for the dog or puppies to get tangled in. Ensure that carpets are maintained free 
from loose strings.  
Correct by 8/29/2023. 
3.10(a) 
   
Watering 
Dogs in the raised enclosure (#58 and #27) and a beagle (#66) with puppies had water dishes that were empty. Other 
dogs in the facility have a continuous water system. When given water, these dogs drank in a manner that suggested they 
were moderately thirsty. Lack of water can cause health problems in dogs. Ensure that all dogs have continuous access 
to potable water.  
Maintain correct by 8/29/2023. 
3.11(a) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
There was excessive soiled waste under the four raised whelping enclosures closest to the entry door. When examining 
these dogs inside their enclosures stronger odors were noted and some flies were on the waste. The licensee said areas 
underneath (where dogs don't contact it) is cleaned twice weekly. Since stronger odors were observed and flies were on 
the waste, more frequent cleaning is needed of this area. Odors and flies can cause discomfort and sickness in dogs. 
Ensure that areas under these enclosures are cleaned more often to prevent odors and pests such as flies.  
Correct by 8/30/2023. 
3.13(b)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
Facility representatives said a spray product (Adams Plus) has been used on dogs since July when fleas were seen. A 
record of when and which dog was given this product wasn't kept. The names of treatments given and the dates they are 
given and to which dog is required to be kept in records and is important for animal health monitoring. Ensure that 
accurate records are kept that show what treatments were given to which animal and the date given.  
Correct from this day forward. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
